content: This is how internet access in Japan works. In Tokyo, the city is divided into a few regions, where each region has a single, highly regulated fiber provider. You pay a nominal (~$10/mo) “fiber access fee”. Then, there are a dozen ISPs who all sell access to the fiber, competing on speed, bandwidth and price. You are free to choose any ISP, and they run from about $15-$40/mo for up to 1Gbps+. Furthermore, ISPs are regulated and are not allowed to be in the content business, a’la Comcast or Time Warner.
